sn7.8:3.1: For him, the “three knowledges” would have been the Vedas.
sn7.8:3.4: An oblation of milk-rice may be offered to various deities, and is commonly associated with fertility rites. It should be offered to brahmins (eg. Khādira Gṛhyasūtra 4.3; Pāraskara Gṛhyasūtra 3.9.8; Gobhila Gṛhyasūtra 3.8, 4.6.13; Śāṅkhāyana Gṛhyasūtra 3.11.16, 4.16.5), but only those who study the Vedas (Gautama Dharmasūtra 1.5.30). It should not be cooked for one’s own consumption (Manu 5.7). It counteracts inauspicious dreams (Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka 11.4). Manu 3.271 says such an offering is efficacious for a year. Compare Snp 3.4, where rice cake is offered instead. | Somaṁ is so imaṁ, not a reference to soma.
sn7.8:5.1: This verse sets out the Buddha”s “three knowledges”: recollection of past lives, clairvoyance of rebirth, and ending of rebirth.
sn7.8:8.1: See SN 2.9:7.3 and note. Also note that, while gāthā is sometimes said to exclude Vedic verse, this is not the case (see eg. Rig Veda 1.190.01, 8.71.14, 8.92.02; Atharva Veda 10.10.20, 15.6.4, 20.103.1; 3.2.4.16; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.5.3.11, 13.1.5.6; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.17.9). It was, however, said to be a distinct form of verse within the broader Vedic corpus (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.6.8,  11.5.7.10).
sn7.8:8.4: “Since there is such a principle” is dhamme sati, “there being the law of nature”.
